awd_titl_txt: ABI Sustaining: The CIPRES Science Gateway, a Resource for Biological Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the evolution of life on earth is of fundamental importance in virtually every field of modern biology. The study of evolutionary relationships helps researchers understand and respond to the origin and spread of viruses, develop strategies to preserve existing species, mitigate the impact of invasive species, and determine how environmental changes impact populations, shaping local and global ecologies. The information obtained from evolutionary research informs both agricultural and medical policies, two areas where the potential impact on national and global economies is substantial. At present, evolutionary research is critically dependent on the analysis of large amounts of DNA sequence data. Phylogenetic analyses and population genetics studies of sequence data are computationally intensive and are accomplished most efficiently through access to powerful high performance computing resources. This project will sustain the operation of the CIPRES Science Gateway, a premiere web service for analyzing sequence data that has provided 30,000+ researchers around the world with easy access to high‐performance computers at no charge. CIPRES lets individual investigators and multi‐national research teams analyze their data anywhere an internet connection is available, and it makes running the analyses as easy as possible for researchers with little knowledge of high‐performance computing. Analyses run by CIPRES produce results 10‐to‐100‐fold faster than is possible on a laptop computer. As a result, comprehensive studies can be completed more quickly, and large studies that are not practical on laptop computers can now be completed successfully. CIPRES thus dramatically improves researcher productivity and democratizes access to high‐performance computing, allowing investigators to contribute to the growing understanding of evolution on earth, independent of their local resources. The impact of CIPRES on the rate of discovery has been substantial; it has supported more than 4,500 published research studies since 2010 and has been used by 90+ instructors in classroom environments. 
 
CIPRES currently supports 10,000+ researchers annually who are investigating the evolutionary history of proteins, viruses, bacteria, plants, and animals; identifying new genera and species; evaluating and developing new techniques; and exploring the evolutionary history of diverse populations. This project will sustain the continued online presence of CIPRES for these researchers through the following activities: provide browser and RESTful access to current versions of community phylogenetics and population genetics codes deployed on high‐performance computing resources supported separately by the NSF XSEDE project; update the codes and/or usage policies to help users do more computationally demanding analyses; adapt the codes and policies to changes in available XSEDE resources and the local operating environment; modify the underlying software to support new code capabilities and correct any functionality or usability issues that arise; minimize negative impacts of planned and unplanned system outages on hundreds of simultaneous jobs; provide outreach by making presentations at professional meetings and hosting workshops to improve connection with the systematics community; monitor usage statistics to better understand and improve the effectiveness of CIPRES; and procure allocations of supercomputer resources to support the large CIPRES user community. The project will also sustain the CIPRES Workbench Framework, an open source software package that underlies CIPRES and that has been adopted by four other biology communities to create their own gateways. CIPRES can be accessed at http://www.phylo.org.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Here we report outcomes for NSF award 1759844, which supported activities designed to maintain and sustain the CIPRES Science Gateway (CIPRES). CIPRES is a computational resource that serves the biology community. For the past 12 years, CIPRES has provided easy access to 20+ up-to-date phylogenetics and population biology codes run on large compute clusters provided by the NSF XSEDE program. Users from around the world can analyze their phylogenetic and population biology data simply by uploading their data and configuring their analyses through a web browser or web services interface. No additional knowledge of the underlying computers is required; the jobs are automatically configured to run as quickly and efficiently as the code allows. CIPRES is the only public resource for most of these codes. As such, it represents a critical piece of cyberinfrastructure for the global biology community, and for that reason CIPRES is a highly accessed site (10,000+ users per year).

Our maintaining activities during the award period focused on keeping the web site functioning optimally in an ever-changing IT environment. Our activities included software maintenance and systems administration tasks that preserved the operational integrity of job submissions, results storage, and results retrieval capabilities. Users were able to use the web-based graphical user interface and a set of web services that integrated CIPRES capabilities into other science gateways and desktop applications that require phylogenetic analyses. Additional activities included routine updating, benchmarking, and release of current and new community codes; usage monitoring to ensure efficient and prudent use of NSF resources by the user community; user support; adjustments and bug fixes based on feedback from users; and reporting progress.

Our sustaining activities focused on transitioning CIPRES from a resource sustained by federal grant funds into one that is sustained by individual user subscriptions. The award supported a collaboration between the CIPRES team and Phoenix Bioinformatics (a non-profit that supports sustainability for digital biology resources). Through this collaboration, we integrated CIPRES with the Phoenix's software infrastructure for accepting on line payments, and created a "paywall" that requires users to pay for access after their usage reaches a defined threshold (currently 1000 hours).

Outcomes:

1. Maintaining: During the award period, 13,000+ users ran jobs using CIPRES annually. Each year, CIPRES users consumed 20+ million core hours of computer time. CIPRES received job submissions from 200 Ph.D. granting universities in the US. over the past three years, and from 600+ universities outside the US. More than 1,700 peer-reviewed publications were supported by CIPRES in 2021, and at least 4,500 over the three-year award period. User surveys show that 92% of users feel their research benefits from CIPRES. The access provided by CIPRES allowed scientists to quickly investigate the origin and distribution of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, emphasizing the value of CIPRES when scientists need to respond rapidly to an unforeseen, time-sensitive research problem. Clearly, the impact of CIPRES on the progress of biological research was significant. CIPRES was also used by more than 100 instructors to deliver curriculum, primarily to graduate students, but also to undergraduate and high school students. This work was accomplished with less than two full time equivalents of staff time.

2. Sustaining: In January 2021, we implemented a paid subscription service for users outside the US, and in January 2022, we transitioned all users to the subscription model. In our first year of operation under the new model (calendar 2021) we received approximately 200 subscriptions amounting to $33,000. In the first two quarters of 2022, we received an additional 270 subscriptions, and are on track to receive generate approximately $80,000 in revenue in 2022. The current trend suggests it will be possible to sustain CIPRES through the subscription model within the next 2-3 years.


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Mark A Miller

CIPRES is a computational resource that serves the biology community. For the past 12 years, CIPRES has provided easy access to 20+ up-to-date phylogenetics and population biology codes run on large compute clusters provided by the NSF XSEDE program. Our maintaining activities during the award period focused on keeping the web site functioning optimally in an ever-changing IT environment. Users were able to use the web-based  graphical user interface  and a set of web services that integrated CIPRES capabilities into other science  gateways and desktop applications that  require phylogenetic analyses.  Additional activities included  routine updating, benchmarking, and  release of current and new community  codes; usage monitoring to ensure  efficient and prudent use of NSF  resources by the user community; user  support; adjustments and bug fixes  based on feedback from users; and  reporting progress.

Our sustaining activities focused on transitioning CIPRES from a resource sustained by federal grant funds into one that is sustained by individual user subscriptions. The award supported a collaboration between the CIPRES team and Phoenix Bioinformatics (a non-profit that supports sustainability for digital biology resources). Outcomes:

1. Maintaining: During the award period, 13,000+ users ran jobs using CIPRES annually. Each year, CIPRES users consumed 20+ million core hours of computer time. CIPRES  received job submissions from 200 Ph.D. granting universities in the US.  over the past three years, and from 600+ universities outside the US. User surveys show that 92% of users feel their research benefits  from CIPRES. Clearly, the impact of CIPRES on the progress of biological research was significant. CIPRES was also used by more than 100 instructors to deliver curriculum, primarily to graduate students, but also to undergraduate and high school students. 2. Sustaining: In January 2021, we implemented a paid subscription service for users outside the US, and in January 2022, we transitioned all users to the subscription model. In our first year of operation under the new model (calendar 2021) we received approximately 200 subscriptions amounting to $33,000. In the first two quarters of 2022, we received an additional 270 subscriptions, and are on track to receive generate approximately $80,000 in revenue in 2022. The current trend suggests it will be possible to sustain CIPRES through the subscription model within the next 2-3 years.
